channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jackie Collins, Novelist Who Wrote of Hollywood’s Glamorous Side, Dies at 77
item.description: Ms. Collins, sister of the actress Joan Collins, had been battling breast cancer, her family said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH ROSEN
item.media:description: Jackie Collins, left, with her sister, the actress Joan Collins, at the 2009 Vanity Fair Oscar party in West Hollywood, Calif.

item.title: Noël Verset, Vigneron Who Helped Save a Wine Tradition, Dies at 95
item.description: Mr. Verset’s perseverance laboring in vineyards in the Rhône Valley of France, helped the Cornas appellation survive to be discovered by a new generation of wine lovers.
item.dc:creator: ERIC ASIMOV
item.media:description: Noël Verset in Cornas, in the Rhône Valley of France, in around 1985.

item.title: Islamic Militants Kill 56 Captive Syrian Soldiers
item.description: The Nusra Front, an affiliate of Al Qaeda, killed dozens of Syrian government soldiers who had been taken prisoner when a northern air base was captured this month.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Cubans Have Mixed Opinions on Effect of Visit by Pope Francis
item.description: As Pope Francis arrives for a four-day stay in Cuba, residents wonder if he will speak publicly about political freedom and what change, if any, his visit will bring to the nation.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Havana welcoming Pope Francis, a Latin American who appeals to Cubans by speaking of the ills of capitalist systems and about social equality.

item.title: U.N. Funding Shortfalls and Cuts in Refugee Aid Fuel Exodus to Europe
item.description: Refugees who cannot get assistance where they are will risk travel, aid officials say, especially when Europe seems to beckon.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: A volunteer offered food to migrants packed on a train in Roszke, Hungary, last week. The train was headed to Austria’s border.

item.title: U.S. and China Seek Arms Deal for Cyberspace
item.description: The countries are discussing what could be the first arms control accord for cyberspace, and an agreement could be announced as soon as Thursday, according to officials.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Obama and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, last November. They are hoping to announce an agreement this week.

item.title: Pope Francis, Arriving in Cuba, Seeks to Revive Church
item.description: Francis, who arrived in Havana on Saturday, the first stop of a nine-day papal trip to Cuba and the United States, must try to fully open up the country to the Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY, AZAM AHMED and VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: Pope Francis is welcomed in Havana by President Raul Castro of Cuba.

item.title: Francis In America: Latino Catholics See Reflection in a Friar Set for Sainthood
item.description: When Pope Francis canonizes him on Wednesday, Junípero Serra, a Spanish friar who founded nine Catholic missions in California, will become the first Hispanic saint from the United States.
item.dc:creator: FERNANDA SANTOS
item.media:description: The Rev. Tom Elewaut, the pastor of Mission San Buenaventura in Ventura, Calif., holding a holy card commemorating the canonization of its founder, the Rev. Junípero Serra, which is slated for Wednesday.

item.title: Greeks Vote on Whether to Give Leftists Another Chance
item.description: Alexis Tsipras, the Greek leftist who lost his fight with Europe’s establishment to end its harsh economic austerity against his country, seeks re-election on Sunday, a month after he resigned as prime minister.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras, fourth from left, the leader of the leftist Syriza party, met with young people at a coffee shop in Athens on Saturday. Mr. Tsipras resigned as Greece’s prime minister last month to call new elections, which will be held on Sunday.

item.title: Thousands Flood Into Austria as Migrants Are Bounced Around Europe
item.description: Thousands of migrants poured into Austria on Saturday after being bounced around the Balkans, as Hungary grudgingly allowed at least 11,000 to enter from Croatia.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and PALKO KARASZ
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants waited Saturday at Croatia’s Harmica border crossing, hoping to be allowed into Slovenia and, eventually, Austria.

item.title: Francis in America: A Humble Pope, Challenging the World
item.description: Francis, the first Latin American pope, has drawn from his life in Argentina to try to create a humbler papacy, albeit one with lofty ambitions. His push for change has stirred hope and anxiety.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis aboard his popemobile in July in Asunción, Paraguay.

item.title: Leader of Protests Against Caste Quotas in India Is Detained
item.description: Clashes erupted in parts of western India on Saturday as the police detained the popular leader of a well-to-do caste group that is fighting India’s entrenched quota system.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Warily Eyeing China, Philippines May Invite U.S. Back to Subic Bay
item.description: With China pressing its claim to a vast expanse of sea west of Subic Bay, the Philippines is debating whether to welcome the United States Navy back to its old base.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The crew of a small fishing vessel docked in the waters of Subic Bay.

item.title: Facebook Group’s Push for Safe Land Passage for Migrants Founders
item.description: The effort showed the determination of asylum seekers to gain a coherent policy that will help them make their journeys and save lives.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: BORYANA DZHAMBAZOVA
item.media:description: A migrant boy played a violin as hundreds of migrants, blocked by the police, camped near Edirne, Turkey, on Saturday.

item.title: Arab Coalition Bombs Yemen’s Capital, Killing Dozens
item.description: Saudi-led airstrikes targeted government buildings and residential neighborhoods in Sana overnight on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Tourists Thwart Turtles from Nesting in Costa Rica
item.description: During the first weekend in September, day-trippers swarmed the beach in Costa Rica that serves as a nesting ground for olive ridley sea turtles, becoming a cautionary tale for conservationists, not to mention a social media sensation.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: The effects of El Niño helped ease access to Ostional Beach in Costa Rica, drawing tourists who disrupted sea turtle nesting.

item.title: Russian Buildup in Syria Raises Questions on Role
item.description: The deployment of air defense systems and fighter aircraft has spurred concerns that Moscow’s goal includes establishing a military outpost in the Middle East.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Abandoning Afghan War Zone in a Perilous Quest for Europe
item.description: Many are leaving the northern city of Kunduz, taking advantage of a break in fighting to set out across the Iranian desert to an uncertain fate.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Documents in hand, hundreds of Afghan passport applicants lined up before sunrise, outside Afghanistan's only passport office, in the country's capital, Kabul.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: In Sierra Leone, Giving the Stigma of Ebola a Good, Swift Kick
item.description: An all-survivors soccer team led by Erison Turay was made to bring Ebola survivors together and create a new community from the shared pain of the past.
item.dc:creator: BEN C. SOLOMON

item.title: 17,000 Migrants Stranded in Croatia by Border Crackdown
item.description: Barred from Hungary, sent packing from Serbia and unable to enter Slovenia, many are finding themselves boxed in.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A boy pushed against a police officer’s shield as Syrian refugees and migrants marched through Edirne, Turkey, on Friday, in the direction of Greece.
